title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(skimr)
library(viridis)

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Common Code

p1 <- ggplot(data=diamonds, aes(x=cut))

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Bar chart: Counts

p1 + geom_bar()








Add color

p1 + geom_bar(fill="forestgreen")








Add title









Add sequential colour theme

p1 + geom_bar(aes(fill=cut))+
  scale_fill_viridis_d() + 
  labs(title="Composition of diamonds by cuts")








Change color pallet

p1 + geom_bar(aes(fill=cut))+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "magma") + 
  labs(title="Composition of diamonds by cuts")








Manually fill colors
p1 + geom_bar(aes(fill=cut))+
  scale_fill_manual(<>) + 
  labs(title="Composition of diamonds by cuts")

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Bar charts: percentages

Method 1: geom_col

diamonds |> 
  summarize(prop = n() / nrow(diamonds), .by = cut) 

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  cut         prop
  <ord>      <dbl>
1 Ideal     0.400 
2 Premium   0.256 
3 Good      0.0910
4 Very Good 0.224 
5 Fair      0.0298



diamonds |> 
  summarize(prop = n() / nrow(diamonds), .by = cut) |> 
  mutate(cut = forcats::fct_reorder(cut, prop))

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  cut         prop
  <ord>      <dbl>
1 Ideal     0.400 
2 Premium   0.256 
3 Good      0.0910
4 Very Good 0.224 
5 Fair      0.0298



diamonds |> 
  summarize(prop = n() / nrow(diamonds), .by = cut) |> 
  mutate(cut = forcats::fct_reorder(cut, prop)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(y=prop, x=cut)) +
  geom_col()










Method 2: geom_bar and after_stat

ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = after_stat(count / sum(count)))) +
  geom_bar()








Flip coords

ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = after_stat(count / sum(count)))) +
  geom_bar() + 
  coord_flip()








Obtain percentage

ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = after_stat(count / sum(count)*100))) +
  geom_bar() + 
  coord_flip()

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Bi-variate

Stacked bar chart
Encoding by colour
Position: stack

b1 <- ggplot(data=diamonds, aes(x=cut, fill=color))

R code:___________











Grouped bar chart/ Cluster bar chart
This chart displays bars for multiple categories grouped together side by side.
Encoding by colour
Position: dodge
R code:___________











Small Multiples or Trellis Chart
This chart displays multiple small bar charts, each representing a different subset of the data.
Encoding by position

ggplot(data=diamonds, aes(x=color))+geom_bar()+facet_wrap(~cut)








Your turn: What is the best chart: grouped bar chart, stack bar chart or faceting?


Percentage stacked bar chart

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Cleveland dot chart
This is useful when you have large number of categories.
















Representation using bar chart









Question: What is the best representation? Dot chart or Bar chart?

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Plotting Summary statistics: Method 1
Calculate summary statistics before plotting.
R code:___________________


# A tibble: 5 × 2
  cut       mean_carat
  <ord>          <dbl>
1 Fair           1.05 
2 Good           0.849
3 Very Good      0.806
4 Premium        0.892
5 Ideal          0.703


R Code:________________










Plotting summary statistics: Method 2 - with stat_summary
Common code

g1 <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = carat)) 

Plot mean values.

g1+
  stat_summary(fun.y = "mean", geom="point", color="red")








Your turn: Plot mean and median.
R code:___________________









R code:___________________
mean_se: mean and standard error









R code:___________________
mean_cl_normal: 95 per cent confidence interval assuming normality. (Use library(Hmisc))

library(Hmisc)
g1+stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_cl_normal")








R code:___________________
mean_cl_boot: Bootstrap confidence interval (95%)









Confidence limits provide us a better idea than standard error limits of whether two means would be deemed statistically different.

title: Visualising Qualitative Data
text:
Design of Experiments
Description
The response is the length of odontoblasts (cells responsible for tooth growth) in 60 guinea pigs. Each animal received one of three dose levels of vitamin C (0.5, 1, and 2 mg/day) by one of two delivery methods, orange juice or ascorbic acid (a form of vitamin C and coded as VC).

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Packages we need today

library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Pioneers


Concept: Leland Wilkinson


Implementation: Hadley Wickham

title: The Grammar of Graphics
section: Building Blocks of layers with the grammar of graphics
text:
Building Blocks of layers with the grammar of graphics

Data
Aesthetics
Geometrics
Facets
Scales
Statistics
Coordinates
Themes

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Step 1: Take Data

data(penguins)

title: The Grammar of Graphics
section: Step 2: Take a canvas to do the plot
text:
Step 2: Take a canvas to do the plot

ggplot()

title: The Grammar of Graphics
section: Take your data onto your canvas for plotting
text:
Take your data onto your canvas for plotting

ggplot(data=penguins)

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text: Data + Aesthetics

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Data + Aesthetics + Geom

ggplot(data=penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm, y=body_mass_g, col= species)) +
geom_point()

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Data + Aesthetics + Geom + Facet

ggplot(data=penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm, y=body_mass_g, col= species)) +
geom_point() + 
facet_wrap(~species)

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Data + Aesthetics + Geom + Facet + Scale

ggplot(data=penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm, y=body_mass_g, col= species)) +
geom_point() + 
facet_grid(species ~ island) + 
scale_colour_manual(values = c("#1b9e77","#d95f02","#7570b3"))

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Data + Aesthetics + Geom + Facet + Stat

ggplot(data=penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm, y=body_mass_g, col= species)) +
geom_point() + 
facet_grid(species ~ island) +
scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
stat_summary(
    geom = "point",
    fun.y = "mean",
    col = "black",
    size = 7,
    shape = 24,
    fill = "red",
    alpha = 0.5,
  )

title: STA 492 2.0/ASP 460 2.0 Data Visualisation
text:
Due date:
15 May 2024
Assignment 1:
10 marks
Task:

Capture a photograph demonstrating the application of Gestalt laws.
Explain how the Gestalt principles were utilized in your photograph.
You can use any location to take your photograph.
You must document your work in an RMarkdown document. Your work should be fully reproducible. That means, you should submit your .Rmd file, .html file and any attachments. The best reports will be published on the course’s website.

Academic Integrity Notice:
Plagiarism Policy: Reports found to be plagiarized will receive a score of 0 for the assignment.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Perceiving

What do I see?: Reading the chart


What data is shown?
What is on x-axis/ y-axis?
What do colours represent?
What range of values are displayed?
Stepped magnitude judgement?
Where are the least and most/ average?/largest and smallest?

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Interpreting

Translate what you see into quantitative and/or qualitative meaning
Reader’s ability to perform relational interpretation

Are these patterns normal, expected or unusual?
What features are interesting?
What features are important given the subject knowledge?



If you do not have any knowledge about the subject your understanding stops after the perceiving phase.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Comprehending

What does it mean to me?


What does one do with this understanding?
Have I learned something I did not know before?
Was it confirmed I did not know before?

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Exploratory vs Explanatory


Exploratory

When you have a whole bunch of data and you are not sure what types of trends, relationships, etc. it contains.
Find the story that the data has to tell you.


Explanatory

When you already know what the data has to say and you are trying to tell that story to somebody else.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Three important parties

Data
Designer
Reader

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Data

Categorical?
Ordinal?
Discrete or continuous?
How they are bounded?
Netwroks/ trees/ hierarchy
Collection of items, groups, sets, clusters
Spatial field: scalar, vector, tensor
Outliers
How many dimensions?

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Designer

Planning:


What is the output format? (printout, mobile app, etc)
Time scale
Tools
Who is your audience (How much assistance do they need?, How familiar are they with the charts?)
Identify the goal

What point or message are you trying to convey?
What information should they be able to learn from your visualisations?
Examples: Compare performances, Identify trends, Find outliers, Find relationshsips

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Reader

Contextual considerations for the reader


Perceiving: What do colors means? What is on x-axis, y-axis?
In what direction does the reader follow the plot?
Which types of plots are they familiar with?

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Proximity
We perceive objects close to each other as belonging to a group.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Similarity
Our brain group objects that share the same colour, shape, and direction

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Enclosure
We perceive objects as belonging to a group when they are enclosed in a way that creates a boundary or border around them.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Closure
Our brains tend to complete missing parts in the picture.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Connectedness
We perceive objects connected to each other as a single group.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Continuity
Humans tendency is to see shapes as continuous to the greatest degree possible. The human eye/brain follows lines, curves or a sequence of shapes to create pathways.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Figure and Ground
Human’s ability to visually differentiate between an object and its background.
Example 1:

Example 2: Click here: https://thiyangt.github.io/coviddashboard/

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Simplicity
The law of simplicity indicates that our mind perceives everything in its simplest form.

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Common fate
When objects move in the same direction or at a similar pace, our brains automatically group them together. (eg: a flock of birds)


NULL

title: Introduction to Data Visualisation
text:
Exercise
Draw a plot to show the relationship between Life Expectancy and Countries

library(gapminder)
library(tidyverse)
gapminder |>
  filter(year == 2007, continent == "Americas") |>
  select(country, lifeExp)

# A tibble: 25 × 2
   country            lifeExp
   <fct>                <dbl>
 1 Argentina             75.3
 2 Bolivia               65.6
 3 Brazil                72.4
 4 Canada                80.7
 5 Chile                 78.6
 6 Colombia              72.9
 7 Costa Rica            78.8
 8 Cuba                  78.3
 9 Dominican Republic    72.2
10 Ecuador               75.0
# ℹ 15 more rows

text:
Acknowledgement

Kirk, A. (2016). Data visualisation: a handbook for data driven design
Gestalt Laws Applied to Data Visualization, https://daydreamingnumbers.com/

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
#install.packages("GGally")
library(GGally)
ggpairs(elephants)

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text: ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 3, 4))

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text: ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9))

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text: ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender))

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text: ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender)) + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2")

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text: ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender)) + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2")

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text: ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender)) + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + theme_bw()

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender, alpha=0.5)) + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + theme_bw()


Your turn: Fix aspect ratio of the plots.

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
Beware!

ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender, alpha=0.5)) + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + coord_fixed(ratio=ar)

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
Beware!

ggpairs(elephants, columns = c(2, 8, 9), mapping=aes(color=Gender, alpha=0.5)) + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Dark2") + theme(aspect.ratio = ar)

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
library(patchwork)
p1+p2

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
library(cowplot)
plot_grid(p1, p2, labels = c('A', 'B'), label_size = 12)

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
library(ggstatsplot)
ggbetweenstats(
  data  = elephants,
  x     = Gender,
  y     = Height,
  title = "Distribution of height by gender"
)

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
To visualize the distribution of a single variable and check if its mean is significantly different from a specified value with a one-sample test

gghistostats(
  data       = elephants,
  x          = Height,
  title      = "Height of Elephants",
  test.value = 2.5,
  binwidth   = 0.5
)

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
library("ggpubr")
gghistogram(elephants, x = "Height",
   add = "mean", rug = TRUE,
   color = "Gender", fill = "Gender",
   palette = c( "#e7298a","#081d58"))

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
ggboxplot(elephants, y = "Height", x="Gender",
   color = "Gender",
   palette = c( "#e7298a","#081d58"),
   add = "jitter", shape = "Gender")

title: Beyond Basics: Elevate Your Plots
text:
In-class demo
library("esquisse")
esquisse::esquisser(elephants::elephants)
